name: Binnie Barnes
comments: Film actress whose career spanned the period 1923 to 1973.  Born in England, Barnes became an American citizen.

name: 4 Deep Tones
comments: gospel and R&B vocal group formed in New York City in 1948. Members include George Vereen (first tenor), Calvin Williams (baritone), Furman Haynes (second tenor), Carroll Dean (bass) and Ivy Floyd (tenor).

name: Arne Axelsson
comments: Accordion player.

name: E.W. Stokes
comments: Songwriter

name: Idaho "Tiny" Stokes
comments: Country music singer and bass player originally from Springfield, Missouri.

name: Arthur Scammell
comments: Scammell had a career as a teacher, but he was also a poet, writer (particularly about his native Newfoundland), and singer.  Scammell is credited as the first person to issue a commercial record for the Newfoundland market with his own "Squid Jiggin' Ground".  The Newfoundland and Labrador Arts Council established a writing award in Scammell’s honor in 1985, and the school in his hometown of Change Islands was renamed the A.R. Scammell Academy in 1990.  In 1987, Scammell  was made a Member of the Order of Canada  for “keeping Newfoundland history alive in song, verse and story.”

name: Ols David
comments: Songwriter

name: Ben Steneker
comments: Country music singer, active since 1959 and nicknamed "The Godfather of Dutch Country Music". In 1994 he was inducted into America's Old Time Country Music Hall of Fame.

name: Omar Blondahl
comments: Maritime folk musician (guitar, fiddle and piano) and vocalist.  Blondahl was perhaps better known as "Sagebrush Sam", the name he used for his radio program.

name: The Travellers [CA]
comments: Folk group formed in Toronto and heavily influenced by The Weavers

name: Donna Washington
comments: Soul singer from Los Angeles, active in the early 1980s

name: Bobbe Norris
comments: A jazz singer that began her professional career singing in restaurants and clubs in California, and worked in San Francisco in the late 50s and early 60s. During this period, she was also secretary to the Kingston Trio.

name: Finest Kind
comments: Folk trio based in Ottawa consisting of Ian Robb, Ann Downey, and Shelley Posen.  The band covers a wide range of music from traditional songs of the British Isles and Maritime provinces to gospel and cowboy numbers.

name: Roslyn Kind
comments: Actress, singer and songwriter.

name: Larry Ramos
comments: A guitarist, banjo player, and vocalist with the 1960s American pop band The Association.

name: Ally & Jo
comments: Short lived Euro Pop/Dance duo

name: Passengers [IT]
comments: Disco formation

name: Pamela Hayden
comments: Actress

name: Pappa Bear
comments: Rapper and songwriter

name: David Troy
comments: Co-founder and lead singer of The Diamonds under the name David Somerville.  From 1961 to 1967, under the name David Troy, he worked as a solo act, marketing himself as a folksinger.  Returning to "Somerville", Troy joined The Four Preps in 1967.   In 1969, The Four Preps disbanded, and Somerville and Bruce Belland worked for some five years as a comedy/music act known as Belland & Somerville.  In 1988, Somerville returned to the revived Four Preps as lead singer and worked with the group another 18 years.

name: Paul Ferris
comments: Film composer and actor

name: Mary Corbin
comments: Obscure folksinger from Ishpeming, Michigan.

name: Mr. Day
comments: Soulful band started in Lyon in 2001 by Bruno Hovart and Eric Duperray.

name: De Selvera's
comments: Schlager music duo from Weert consisting of the Jansen sisters: Mieke en Selma (nicknamed "Zus")

name: Anne Romaine
comments: Folk music performer, activist in the American civil rights movement and historian.  She was the co-founder of the Southern Folk Cultural Revival Project, a racially integrated group of traditional music artists who toured the South.

name: Eric Duperray
comments: Singer/guitarist and band leader

name: Annelies de Graaf
comments: Pop singer

name: Becc Lester
comments: New Age/pop singer originally from Memphis, but now based in Orlando, Florida.

name: The Bergerfolk
comments: Folk singing group, consisting of Steve and Phoebe Berger and their five children.

comments: Lyricist

name: Charles H. Hoyt

name: Blue Steele
aliases: Blue Steele and His Orchestra with Vocal Chorus
comments: Band leader from Arkansas

name: Sonny Clapp
aliases: Sunny Clapp and His Band o' Sunshine

name: Franz Koglmann

name: Peter Duchin
aliases: Peter Duchin His Piano and Orchestra
Peter Duchin His Piano and Rhythm

name: La Locomotora Negra

name: Kerry Beaumont

name: Allison Girvan

name: Bo Hansson
comments: Initially a guitarist, Bo Hansson later took up keyboards, especially the Hammond organ. Playing Hammond, he recorded three instrumental albums with drummer Janne Carlsson in the late 1960s, followed by four solo albums in the 1970s. The first, containing music inspired by "The Lord of the Rings", was very successful and helped launch the Silence label.

name: Janne Carlsson
comments: Mostly known as an actor and TV presenter, Carlsson has also played in several groups as a jazz-influenced drummer. His nickname was "Loffe" and he even performed with musicians such as Dexter Gordon, Johnny Griffin and Jimi Hendrix. With his storband (= big band), he staged partly weird performances.

name: Joel Helleny
comments: Trombonist most often heard playing jazz.  He also recorded for film.

name: Mark Lotz
comments: Jazz flautist who has been active in the Netherlands jazz scene since the late 1990s.

name: Sue Massek
comments: Folksinger, banjo player, songwriter, and activist for social justice.  She has been a member of the Reel World String Band since its formation in 1977.

name: David Hentschel
comments: An English recording engineer, movie composer and music producer who engineered on George Harrison's "All Things Must Pass" and Elton John's "Goodbye Yellow Brick Road".

name: Paul Hubweber
comments: Modern/Free Jazz and improvising trombonist. Known in Jazz circles for performing slo-mo versions of Charlie Parker songs. For a couple of years in the 1970s also co-organizer of the prestigious annual Moers Jazz Festival.

name: Alex Morsey
comments: Jazz composer, double bass and tuba player

name: Simon Camatta
comments: Drummer, percussionist, theater music composer/musician and improvising artist

name: Gerhard Horriar
comments: Lyricist and vocal artist

name: Rockie Robbins

name: The Yellow Snow Crystals

name: Jana
comments: Singer, songwriter and actress

name: John Verity

name: Ila Vann
comments: R&B and blues singer

name: Walter Kolomoku
comments: Hawaiian steel guitarist and bandleader. He appeared in the first Broadway staging of "Bird of Paradise" and toured the U.S. in the early 1900s. Kolomoku provided lessons through correspondence to country and western swing musician, Bob Dunn after Dunn became interested in the steel guitar upon hearing Hawaiian musicians in Oklahoma. Subsequently, Dunn was one of the first to electrify a guitar.

name: Cliff Crofford
comments: American musician & songwriter.

name: Sons of Serendip
comments: Harp, piano, cello, and voice quartet. The group, which formed while its members were pursuing graduate degrees at Boston University, placed fourth on season 9 of the television show America’s Got Talent.

name: Grubstake
comments: Trio formed in 1972 that plays traditional folk, blues and works by contemporary singer-songwriters.  Each of the trio has a day job, but they have continued to find time to play together.

name: Domenick Fleres
comments: Songwriter

name: Gungor
comments: Baroque pop, folk, and experimental rock-influenced collective centered on the husband-and-wife duo of Michael and Lisa Gungor. Although Gungor grew out of a Christian musical background and have often included spiritual concepts in their music, they do not consider themselves a Contemporary Christian Music band.

name: James Durbin
comments: Rock singer-songwriter and guitarist from Santa Cruz, California. Durbin finished in fourth place on the tenth season of American Idol.

name: Jessie James Decker
comments: Country pop singer-songwriter. She stars with her husband Decker in the E! reality show Eric & Jessie: Game On.

name: Eric Decker
comments: Professional football player. He stars with his wife Jessie James Decker in the E! reality show Eric & Jessie: Game On.

name: Eric Jupp
aliases: Eric Jupp His Piano and Orchestra
comments: Composer, arranger, conductor and musician originally from Brighton, England. He moved to Australia in the early 1960s where he appeared regularly on television. He is known for composing the theme music for the long-running popular TV series, "Skippy the Bush Kangaroo."

name: Rising Gael
comments: Celtic group.

name: Pop Noir
comments: Los Angeles-based indie dancerock duo formed by British-born twin brothers Joe and Luke McGarry in 2004, while they were 16-year-old students at the Orange County High School of the Arts.

name: Eck Robertson
comments: Texas-based fiddler born in Delaney, Arkansas.  In 1922, Robertson and his partner Henry Gilliland were the first artists to ever record "country" music.

name: Clifford Gross
comments: Fiddler originally from Kentucky who ultimately ended up in Texas.  He was commonly referred to as "Doc".

name: Muryel Campbell
comments: Guitar player from Texas with the nickname "Zeke".

name: Ladies First
comments: Female acapella group from Indiana University founded by Natalie Perkins and Sarah Gibson

name: Kessinger Brothers
comments: Traditional music duo consisting of Clark Kessinger (fiddle) and his nephew, Luches Kessinger (guitar).

name: Obed Pickard
comments: Founder of the traditional country/old time music music group, The Pickard Family.  Pickard played harmonica, Jew's harp and violin.  He was also a singer.  After his 1926 appearance at the Grand Ole Opry, he became the first singing star on WSM, the home of the Grand Ole Opry.  Pickard also appeared in a few films.

name: Charles Roane
comments: Producer, nicknamed "The Mixologist".

name: Uncle "Am" Stuart
comments: Old-time fiddler who was born and died in Morristown, Tennessee.  Although he was well known as a performer in the southern Appalachian region, his only recordings were 14 sides from a single session for Vocalion in New York circa July 7, 1924.  Gene Austin provided vocals on any of the tunes with lyrics.

name: Das Fitzett
comments: Vocal trio consisting of Walter Fitz, his wife Molly and his brother Gerd.

name: Kristen Hall
comments: Songwriter, singer, founding member of C&W act Sugarland.

name: Catbird Seat
comments: Eclectic Americana Folk band (comprised of Bob Bedell, Rob Griffin, and Brett Norton) following contemporary and traditional forms of folk expression with heavy influences of rock, blues, folk, bluegrass, and other great Americana genres blended to form an eclectic sound of adult alternative music.

name: Feel Like You
comments: Rich Dwiggins (bass and vocal), Eddie Kesler (percussion) and Chris Newton (guitar)

name: York County Boys
comments: Pioneering Canadian bluegrass band formed in 1954. Members include Mike Cameron [guitar] Rex Yetman [mandolin] “Big John" McManaman [banjo] Brian Barron [fiddle] Alfred Leger [bass]

name: Bill Yohey
comments: Primarily an old time fiddler, Yohey also played mandolin, banjo and tenor guitar.

name: Winnie Winston [US]
comments: Country music pedal steel guitar and banjo player

name: The White Brothers
aliases: The White Brothers (The New Kentucky Colonels)
comments: Bluegrass band that was the successor of The Kentucky Colonels .  The members were the three original White brothers, Roland (mandolin), Clarence (acoustic guitar), and Eric Jr. (banjo and double bass) plus Alan Munde (banjo, harmony vocals).  The band was also known as The New Kentucky Colonels but the group was short-lived when Clarence was killed by a drunk driver just a few months after their formation.

name: Curt Bouterse
comments: Ethnomusicologist and folk multi-instrumentalist who primarily plays banjo.

name: Embryo
comments: Munich based group founded in 1969 and considered one of Europe's most important Jazz crossover acts of the 1970s. Their legendary DLP "Embryos Reise" (1979) documented an adventurous trip to India by 'commune' bus and sessions with local musicians they met on the way. In 1981, Uve Müllrich and Michael Wehmeyer split to start "Embryo's Dissidenten", soon renamed "Dissidenten" and mainly releasing electric jams with musicians from Northern Africa. Subsequently, Embryo turned into a collective of improvising artists with on tour partly daily changing line-ups. Although in concerts playing cover versions turning into long improvising sessions, they hardly ever released any.

name: Christian Burchard
comments: Bayreuth (the in Upper Franconia located Wagner town) born influential Jazz/World musician and improvising artist. Burchard played vibraphone, drums, percussions, keyboards, santur and dulcimer, and was also an occasionally improvising vocalist.

name: Howdy Forrester
comments: Country and bluegrass fiddler from Tennessee nicknamed "Big Howdy".

name: Chuck Wayne [US2]
comments: Country and rockabilly artist and songwriter

name: H. C. Brusiel
comments: Songwriter active in California in the 1950s.

name: Perth County Conspiracy
comments: Folk band from Ontario. Started in 1969 and going until ca. 1977. Their last album was recorded during a stay in the then 'communist' East Berlin where they participated in the '5th Festival of Political Songs'. In Canada, it was released using the alias PCCDNEGDR (short for Perth County Conspiracy Does Not Exist German Democratic Republic).

name: The Crowder Brothers
comments: A country music brother act from Madison County, North Carolina,  who recorded in the 1930s.

name: Bornholms Musikexpres
comments: Entertainment trio founded in 1968 from the isle of Bornholm.

name: The Flies [US]

name: Kristen Toedtman
comments: Indie pop singer-songwriter originally from Baltimore, Maryland. Toedtman works out of both Baltimore and Los Angeles.

name: Paul Misraki
comments: Constantinople-born composer of popular music and film scores

name: Louis Ledrich
aliases: Louis Ledrich et son ensemble musette
comments: Accordionist, bandleader and composer

name: Michelle Hylan
comments: Singer - songwriter from Bristol

name: Gene Goforth

name: Skip Gorman

name: John Hickman
comments: Five-string banjo player born in Hilliard, Ohio.  Hickman also teaches banjo and undertakes banjo repair at the Double Stop Fiddle Shop in Guthrie, Oklahoma owned by Byron Berline .

name: Jon McLaughlin

name: Ginny Owens

name: Art Rosenbaum

Rosenbaum has collected songs, particularly in Kentucky and Georgia (where he lives), and his field recordings are archived at, among other institutions, the Library of Congress.

name: The Girl and The Dreamcatcher

name: Ali McGregor

name: Michael Cleveland
comments: Blind bluegrass fiddler.  Cleveland has currently won the International Bluegrass Music Association's Fiddle Performer of the Year award 10 times, which is more than any other fiddler.

name: Martine Tourreil

name: Danny Sanderson

name: Pamela Britton

(1950). Britton's big break came when she was cast as both Celeste Holm 's understudy and as Gertie in the 1943 Broadway production of Oklahoma! . She also played Meg Brockie in the 1947 Broadway production of Brigadoon (1947). When Oklahoma! went on tour, she took over Holm's role as Ado Annie.

name: Susan Johnson
comments: Actress and singer born  in Columbus, Ohio

name: Frank Porretta

name: Al Goodman [US1]
aliases: Al Goodman and His "Flying High" Orchestra
Dean Franconi and His Sound Stage Orchestra
comments: Born in the Ukraine, Goodman immigrated to the United States in his youth.  He was a conductor, musical director, songwriter, pianist and singer.  Goodman was the conductor for many Broadway musicals.  he later was tapped to supervise and conduct the music for the "Colgate Comedy Hour", a variety show on NBC in the early years of television. As a conductor for RCA Victor, he was active in the 1940s and made a large number of recordings.  These were mostly issued as 78-rpm sets, although these were largely reissued as 45-rpm sets after the introduction of the 45-rpm record.  Goodman also recorded some sides that were released as singles.

name: The Blue Echoes
comments: Formed in 1957, this group is still active as of 2015 and claims to have been Lansing, Michigan's first rock 'n' roll band.  The Blue Echoes are more precisely known as a rockabilly outfit, and they are included as one of Rockabilly's "legends" by the on-line Rockabilly Hall of Fame.

name: James Corden

name: VOOV

name: Tadao Sawai

name: Hozan Yamamoto

comments: A multi-instrumentalist on string instruments, Smeck had the nickname "Wizard of the Strings".  Smeck also designed string instruments.  From Reading, Pennsylvania, Smeck's career started in vaudeville.  Because he was a poor vocalist, he included novelties in his act, for instance, playing the ukulele with his teeth.  In 2001, Smeck was inducted into the National Four-String Banjo Hall of Fame in the performance category.

name: Selma Reis

name: The Swinghufvuds
comments: Instrumental jazzy band featuring Tommi Lindell, Pekka Witikka, Vesa Anttila, Kimmo Kajasto & Pera Pirkola.

name: Jari Esbeukman

name: Janet Godfrey

name: Zuzu Bollin

name: Ken Remo

During the 1950s and 1960s he appeared frequently on television including the Loretta Young Show, Sid Caesar Show, Tennessee Ernie Show. Danny Kaye Show and Chevy Show. On Broadway he appeared in Oklahoma, King and I, Kismet and Song of Norway.

name: The Hillmen

The Hillmen consisted of Chris Hillman (later of The Byrds & The Flying Burrito Brothers) on mandolin, country singer/songwriter Vern Gosdin on guitar and lead vocals, his brother Rex Gosdin on double bass, and Don Parmley (later of the Bluegrass Cardinals) on banjo.

name: Trevor Jones

name: Richard Boone [US1]

name: Gery Scott

Scott made her first recordings in Calcutta, and during the late-1950s and early-1960s, she recorded extensively in the former Czechoslovakia.  Scott traveled and lived in many countries. In 1980, she moved to Australia.

name: Jane Campedelli
aliases: Jane Campedelli with Heritage Jazz Band

name: Betty Comora

He added writing, choreography, directing and producing -- all of which he had done on stage in the approximately 24 Broadway productions with which he was involved by 1932.  Commencing in 1928, he also began directing films.  For several years these were mostly shorts, but by 1934, he was regularly directing features.  Starting in the 1950s, he also produced and directed for television.  Santley was the name of his stepfather.

name: Marion Davies
comments: Actress on stage and in film -- both silent and talkies.  Davies last film was made in 1937. After establishing a reputation as an actress, she began a romantic relationship with the publisher William Randolph Hearst, with whom she ultimately lived for over 30 years.  Hearst actively promoted Davies' career, but this may have been more of a hindrance than a help.  Hearst and Davies were apparently the parents of Patricia Van Cleve Lake, who became the wife of Arthur Lake.  Davies claimed Patricia as her neice.  A rumor also persists that Hearst accidentally shot Thomas Ince leading to Ince's death.  Ince was a producer, director and actor in silent films.  Supposedly the bullet was intended for Charlie Chaplain, who Hearst believed was having an affair with Davies.  Hearst suffered financial reversals in the late 1930s, and Davies bailed him out by selling some $1 million in jewelry. Davis was civic-minded, and donated substantial sums to charitable causes, including almost $2 million in 1952 to establish a children's medical clinic at UCLA, which since 1998 has been known as the Mattel Children's Hospital, although UCLA's medical center continues to maintain a Marion Davies Clinic. Davies died of stomach cancer.

name: Judy Cannon
comments: Singer.  Cannon grew up in Melbourne, and in 1958 became the vocalist in The Thunderbirds, one of Melbourne's earliest rock 'n' roll bands.  In the early-1960s, she moved to Sydney where she was a regular on "Bandstand", "Six O’Clock Rock" and "The Johnny O’Keefe Show". After Channel 7 refused to increase her pay in 1963, Cannon moved to London where she worked as a singer and eventually as an actress.

name: Anna Moffo

She became very popular in Italy where she was the host of  her own opera program on television.  Moffo is legendary in the opera community, but her voice became unreliable by the end of the 1960s, and she retired from the opera in 1974.

name: Libby Morris

name: Barbara Jean English

In 1964, English went solo, and released two albums and some singles as a soul singer.  In the late-1970s, she turned to disco.  In the 1990s, she toured the oldies circuit as a member of the reformed Clickettes.

Some sources give his year of birth as 1925.  I am using the year of birth that is given in Kernfeld, "The New Grove Dictionary of Jazz", 2d ed.

Messina and Viola were later replaced by Tom Sakelakis (tenor saxophone, clarinet, flute) and Paul Lajoie (bass).
